text: Colour multiplier for external reflection. It should be used sparingly, as a non-white value breaks physicality.

Colour multiplier for rays going inside the medium (covers external transmission and internal reflection). It should be used sparingly, as a non-white value breaks physicality. The prefered way to define the colour of a dielectric is through the Interior attributes right below.

Switches the Fresnel between Artistic and Scientific parameters. The Artistic mode offers reflectivity in the normal direction and reflectivity90 at the grazing angle. The Scientific mode provides an index of refraction for each rgb component. Note that IOR is only used to calculate the reflectivity value used by the Schlick approximation. When reflectivity90 is 1, then both modes achieve identical results, as one can be mapped to the other.
Colour reflected by the surface in the normal direction. Corresponds to specColor.

Index of refraction (often denoted by 'eta'), defining the amount reflected by the surface in the normal direction, and how the rays are bent by refraction. A separate value can be specified for each colour channel, if desired.
Colour reflected by the surface at the grazing angle. Should be kept at 1,1,1 for most materials. Corresponds to specColor90.
The inverse of the exponent to use for Schlick.
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.
Indicates how pronounced the tail effect should be, ranging linearly from none at all, to full tail roughness.
Defines how rough the tail effect should appear, ranging from no roughness change at all, to a roughness of 1 (or to 0 with a negative value).

Defines the roughness in the co-tangent direction, giving anisotropic reflection if the value differs from the roughness parameter value. A negative value (the default) means use the original roughness value, i.e. no anisotropy.
Overrides the surface tangent as the anisotropy direction.
Rotates the anisotropy direction (possibly overriden by the previous attribute) around the normal, from 0 to 360 degrees.
Switch between the using spread (a multiplier on the IOR) and Abbe number to specify the strength of the dispersion effect.
Defines how wide the dispersion effect spreads the refracted rays by acting as a multiplier on the IOR. A value of 0 disables the dispersion effect.

The Abbe number models the ammount of dispersion in transmissive materials for the visible spectrum. Lower numbers result in higher dispersion effects. A useful range is 20-85. A value of zero disables dispersion.
Defines the saturation of the dispersion coloration.

Interior volume absorption colour. It is defined as the negative logarithm of the extinction coefficient, with values between 0 and 1, such that the object itself and its shadows are tinted proportionnally. If set to 1, there is no absorption, and if set to 0, the object will be completely opaque. Note that for single scattering to kick in, the value must be inferior to 1. This value will also act as coating colour, when this node is used as top layer in a stack.
Distance, in world space units, at which the Absorption Colour is assumed to be reached. Can be used to control the rate of absorption.

Colour (aka scattering albedo) of the medium, defines what proportion of the light hitting volumetric particles is scattered around by the phase function (as opposed to just absorbed), for each colour channel. Only takes effect if the corresponding channel has a non-null density, in other words if the Absorption Colour value for that channel is inferior to 1.
Anisotropy of the medium’s phase function, ranging from full backward scattering at -1 to forward scattering at 1. Only takes effect if the Scatter Colour is non-null.
Use the named volume aggregate as interior. If set, this overrides all other interior volume settings.

Defines how dense (or opaque) shadows should appear, ranging from no shadows at all at 0, to full shadows at 1. Note that their appearance is affected by the Colouring, Fresnel Front and Back attributes, and that it is possible to obtain 'white' shadows that would not be visible, no matter what Density value is used (by setting Colouring to 1 with a white Transmission Filter, and both Fresnel attributes to 0).
Defines the shadow colour, ranging from black at 0, to the colour set as Transmission Tint at 1.
Defines how much the Fresnel transmission coefficient affects the result, when a shadow ray crosses front-facing geometry.
Defines how much the Fresnel transmission coefficient affects the result, when a shadow ray crosses back-facing geometry.
When enabled, the IOR and refracted rays from layers above will be ignored, and the exterior IOR will be set manually.
Defines what the IOR of the exterior medium is (can be either the outside medium, eg. air or water, or in case of a layered material, the top layer medium, like plexiglass or varnish).

Indicates how much energy should be added to the lobes, to compensate for the loss inherent to micro-facet models, ranging from no compensation at all, to the expected energy from multiple scattering between the micro-facets. This prevents overly dark results when roughness is high.
When enabled, shadowing from bumped normals is considered. This helps to soften harsh shadow terminators.
Defines by how much the roughness can be increased based on local surface curvature. This can help prevent fireflies.
Defines by how much the roughness can be increased based on motion blur. This can help prevent fireflies.
Defines the name that can be used in LPE AOVs for these lobes.

Several dielectric materials with extinction can share the same lobe name, but if they do, they must have a different interior Id. This is necessary when mixing two dielectric materials with the same lobe name. Note that if their lobe names are different, the interior Id is irrelevant.
Defines the name that can be used by the matte system, to output the weight of this lobe in the final material as an AOV.
